Input File Description

Program: Lazser

TABLE OF CONTENTS

INTRODUCTION

The input is organized in three files: the main input file, the seed file and the rule file.

*****************************************************

Main input file: it must be called "input.dat"

&files

seedfile
rulefile
/
&lattice
idimension
latticetype
neighbourhood
isize
/
&steps
nstep
nprint

*****************************************************

Input file 'seedfile':

Number of atoms in the seed
Lattice type | Seed format
Shift type | Shift
Seed coordinates

*****************************************************

Input file 'rulefile':

Lattice type
Rule type
Rule identity

Main input file input.dat

seedfile CHARACTER 
    Name of the file containing the seed
[Back to Top]
rulefile CHARACTER 
    Name of the file containing the rule
[Back to Top]
idimension INTEGER 
    Dimension of the space. It must be equal to the Cdim variable specified in the makefile. It must be compatible with the 
    lattice type: only the simple cubic lattice can be used with any dimension; honeycomb can be used only in 2 dimensions and 
    the face-centered cubic lattice can only be used in 3 dimensions.
[Back to Top]
latticetype CHARACTER 
    Type of lattice. Accepted values are "sc" (simple cubic), "hc" (honeycomb), "fcc" (face-centered cubic). sc is compatible with any 
    value of idimension, while hc works only with idimension = 2, and
    fcc works only with idimension =3. To ensure that the input files are consistent with each other, 
    the lattice type must be specified also in the seed file and in the rule file.
[Back to Top]
neighbourhood CHARACTER 
    Type of neighbourhood. Accepted values are "moore" and "vonneumann".
[Back to Top]
isize INTEGER 
    Size of the lattice. A simple cubic lattice in 3 dimensions has (isize X isize X isize) cells. fcc lattices are built from simple cubic 
    lattices, cancelling half of the cells. Therefore an fcc lattice has (isize X isize X isize)/2 cells. An hc lattice is a 
    simple cubic lattice with a modified neighbourhood, therefore it has (isize X isize) cells like the sc lattice. 
    The code implements hard-wall boundary conditions, and the boundary cells always have the value of 0. For this reason, we recommend to 
    take a size large enough so that the boundaries do not interfere with the center of the lattice.
[Back to Top]
nstep INTEGER 
    Number of steps.
[Back to Top]
nprint INTEGER 
    The configuration is printed to file every nprint steps.
[Back to Top]
**********************************************************

Seed file

Numer of atoms in the seed INTEGER
Lattice type CHARACTER 
    It must be consistent with the variable latticetype in the main input file.
[Back to Top]
Seed format CHARACTER 
    The coordinates of the occupied cells in the seed can be given in two different formats, "indices" or "coord". Indices are 
    Ndim integers (NDim is the dimension of the space), and works only for 'sc' (simple cubic) lattice type. Coord wants real-space 
    coordinates, and accepts both integer and real numbers. The code performs a check that the points actually lie 
    on the lattice type given in input.
[Back to Top]
Shift type CHARACTER 
    The indices of the occupied cells in the seed can be shifted with respect to the actual coordinates provided in the 
    seed file by using "shift type' and "shift". Shift type can be "manual" or "center". In the "manual" case, the 
    indices of the seed are shifted by the integers indicated by "shift". In the case of "center", the seed is put in the centre 
    of the simulation cell.
[Back to Top]
Shift INTEGER 
    The indices of the occupied cells in the seed can be shifted with respect to the actual coordinates provided in the
    seed file by using "shift type' and "shift". Shift is used only if Shift type is "manual". As many integers have to be provided 
    as dimensions of the lattice.
[Back to Top]
Seed coordinates INTEGER/REAL 
    The coordinates of the occupied cells in the seed, one cell per line. Coordinates are real numbers if 
    Seed format is "coord", are integers if Seed format is "indices".
    In the case of "coord", the code checks that the cells actually lie on the lattice declared in input.
[Back to Top]
**********************************************************

Rule file

Lattice type CHARACTER 
    Type of lattice. It is present here as a check of consistency for the input. It must be equal to the 
    type of lattice specified in the main input and in the seed file (see there for more details).
[Back to Top]
Rule type CHARACTER 
    Type of rule. It can take the values "outer", "outer2", "totalistic", "alltotalistic", "allgrowth". The "generic" 
    rule is not implemented yet. "outer" and "outer2" refer to an outer totalistic rule, and differ by the way in which the 
    rule is specified. "outer" expects "Rule identity" to be a single integer, which corresponds to the C-tilde number 
    defined in Packard and Wolfram, J Stat Phys 38, 901 (1985). "outer2" expects two lines of integers; in the first line, 
    the value of the result is reported for number of occupied neighobouring cells from 0 to Nmax, when the central cell is empty; 
    in the second line, the value of the result is reported for number of occupied neighobouring cells from 0 to Nmax, 
    when the central cell is full. "totalistic" refers to a totalistic rule. "totalistic" expects "Rule identity" to be a single integer, 
    which corresponds to the C number defined in Packard and Wolfram, J Stat Phys 38, 901 (1985). To specify a 
    totalistic rule by giving its action on every configuration, one can in principle use outer2 with some care.
    "alltotalistic" makes a cylce over all totalistic rules. It can be quite slow for large lattices, many dimensions. 
    "allgrowth" makes a cycle over all outer totalistic rules that keep full cells full.
[Back to Top]
Rule identity INTEGER 
    It specifies the identity of the specific rule to be used. The specific form depends on the Rule type 
    (see there for more details).
[Back to Top]
